text:
How can I roll back the time 5 hours in my DateTime column?
For example:
from this *2020-01-12T14:30:00.016*  to  *2020-01-12T09:30:00.016*

Based on the docs, DateTime is unaware or naive when it comes to time zones. It points to using TimeZones.jl. But I'm having trouble doing this.

elements.text:
How can I roll back the time 5 hours in my DateTime column?
For example:
from this
to
Based on the docs, DateTime is unaware or naive when it comes to time zones. It points to using TimeZones.jl. But I'm having trouble doing this.

text:
You can add and subtract hours

```julia> using Dates

julia> t = now()
2021-03-18T19:12:31.359

julia> t - Hour(5)
2021-03-18T14:12:31.359```
What do you mean "I'm having trouble doing this"? Check out the docs on conversions for TimeZones.jl [here](<https://juliatime.github.io/TimeZones.jl/stable/conversions/>).

text: <@UBF9YRB6H> In your opinion, is working with data supposed to be tedious? Or is it more so in my case due to my limited knowledge and experience with it? I'm wondering if after some time my state when working with data will be different.

elements.text: In your opinion, is working with data supposed to be tedious? Or is it more so in my case due to my limited knowledge and experience with it? I'm wondering if after some time my state when working with data will be different.

text:
It's hard!

To put it in perspective, I am currently starting a project using Danish Census data (and I don't speak danish!). There are already some scripts written. I know that it is going to take me months to understand things. So my first step is to go through the existing script and comment literally everything. I leave notes when I don't understand something, I google all the words I don't know, I leave `TODO`s everywhere.

I think part of becoming good at data cleaning is trusting that you will understand things eventually, but the only way to get there is to be super systematic and slow. You learn to trust yourself and slow down, imo.

That said, data cleaning in Julia isn't the most mature part of the ecosystem. I myself have only done a few mid-sized data cleaning projects in Julia (because my jobs have been in R and Stata), so there could be lots of pain points that I don't know about. There is nothing wrong with switching to R or Stata if you feel like the ecosystem isn't ready.

I think part of becoming good at data cleaning is trusting that you will understand things eventually, but the only way to get there is to be super systematic and slow. You learn to trust yourself and slow down, imo.

That said, data cleaning in Julia isn't the most mature part of the ecosystem. text:
<@UBF9YRB6H> I definitely needed to hear this. Working with data in general has always felt like a drag for me and now with Julia it has somewhat thwarted my joy for using this language. I remember feeling this way in other languages after several days of data cleaning as well.

I'm going to work on slowing down and being systematic like you. I have my eyes set on what I'll do with the data and I'm trying to fly through the data cleaning without grasping what's going on which leads to more frustration as I forget what I did the day before.

Yeah I almost felt like I might as well try everything in Julia even the data cleaning but what you've said makes a lot of sense. There should be no shame in doing some cleaning in another language and then once the data is ready for work, make use of it in Julia.

text:
One thing I find helpful is just committing to doing everything with the exact same syntax. When I do data-cleaning, I use `Chain.jl` and `DataFramesMeta` exclusively, even if it's not the most efficient. That cuts down on the mental load for "how do I do this?". When I am doing analysis code, with functions, I always create lots of containers (`struct`s or `NamedTuple`s) and use `@unpack` inside every function.

That way i don't have to worry about which arguments to pass to which functions.

These kinds of things cut down on the mental load of programming and allow you to focus on the data.

inside every function.

That way i don't have to worry about which arguments to pass to which functions.

These kinds of things cut down on the mental load of programming and allow you to focus on the data.

text: I suppose the snide/cynical(/realist?) comment is: "if working with data is easy, you're not doing it well" :sweat_smile::cry:

elements.text: I suppose the snide/cynical(/realist?) comment is: "if working with data is easy, you're not doing it well"
It's very very hard!!

text: I agree with all of the above, but I would also add that while data cleaning is hard, based on your questions here your experience is still quite limited. Now I don't mean to say "you suck", but rather "it will get easier than it is now". You'll have seen that for many of your questions here, people came up with answers immediately, and the answers were often strategies used quite frequently by the experienced analyst. As you go on, you will find that many of those answers will seem natural to you (eg the left join on a complete panel which Peter recommended below to one of your questions), and things will become smoother. However in the end that will mean you'll get stuck on harder problems :joy:
